docs.abstract: Francine Prose article on attractions of New Castle, Del; map; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, i confess, i'd come to think of Delaware as that long, rather terrifying bridge between Maryland and New Jersey -- specifically, the Delaware Memorial Bridge that you cross (and cross and cross) on the way to Washington from New York. So it was a revelation and a pleasure actually to stop in Delaware, and to discover that what lives more or less underneath the bridge is not the troll one might sensibly expect, but rather the attractive town of New Castle. Old and lovely without being cutesy or pretentious, relaxed but high functioning, cared for but not precious, fossilized or overrestored, New Castle is a rarity: a model of historical preservation and small-town civility in which the owner of that adorable brick Federal or imposing ivy-covered Victorian is more likely to drive a pickup truck than a BMW.

headline.main: When Patients Want to Know the Distance to Death's Door

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger comments on difficult questions facing a doctor when a patient with serious disease wants to know how long he has to live (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: My patient Charlie did not show up for his appointment this month, an aberration for which I am deeply, selfishly grateful. It means that he is feeling well, since he never fails to check in at the first ache or sneeze. It also means that I get a little break from the relentless cross-examination that is a session in the office with Charlie. ''How long do I have, doc?'' he asks. ''Say a year, I guess, for sure, right? Am I right? Two?''
